page.title: 16BENENDEN WEALD, POLITICS.
page.content: Government policy has a great effect on farming today and in April l984 milk quotas were imposed on farmers. Forest Farm was told that it was over its quota and so needed to cutback. The farmer was very fortunate in that during the winter of 1983/1984 the cows had a high grade feed, giving a high yield on which the quota was based. When they had sold ten cows they were within their quota. Now in 1985 the herd has stabilised at 108 milking cows with 18 heifers and 33 calves. Friesians are kept because they have a good milk yield, calve easily and are also good for beef. The herd has been built up from two cows which cost Â£34 each, in 1946 to its present size. With the present over production of milk in the E.E.C. there are no plans for further expansion.
